Good advice, and it gives me a good opportunity =
to stress the importance of
test groups.

It is important to group your tes=
ts in various categories, which can
represent several different things depe=
nding on your emphasis.  For example,
you can have "database" tests, "front=
-end" tests, "security" tests, etc...

This kind of grouping is functional,=
 but you can also have a more procedural
grouping:  "check-in" tests (the t=
ests that need to be run before any
submission to the depot), "functional" =
tests (which cover our entire
application", "integration" tests (making sur=
e all the various parts work
well together), etc...

Obviously, one test ca=
n belong to several tests.

The only way you can group tests with JUnit is =
-- like the "test" hack -- by
using Java features:  class and package names=
.

It was good enough back then because there was no choice, but we can do =
much
better now with annotations:

@Test(groups =3D { "check-in", "function=
al", "database" })
public void verifyAddressRecords() {
  ...
}

Notice how=
 orthogonal your business logic is (method name and code) with how
this met=
hod will be interpreted with the test framework.  There is no
interference:=
 it's totally non-intrusive.

Once you have that, it becomes trivial to det=
ach the static model (your test
code) from your runtime model (which tests =
to run) and it becomes much
easier to implement Ilja's suggestion:  "don't =
always run them all".

If you have just modified some database-related code=
, you then need to

- Run all the "check-in" tests (mandatory for everyone)=

- Run the "database" group (just to make sure)
